title: Micro-magnetic resonance imaging of ex vivo mouse embryos with potato starch suspension
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Fixation of the specimens
Timing: 1–2 weeks
Instructions for the protocol of fixation of the specimens are detailed.
Prepare the paraformaldehyde (PFA) and phosphate-buffered saline (PBS).
Dissolve the 1 piece of PBS tablets and 1 mL sodium azide into the 999 mL distilled water.
If a contrast agent is required, solve 10 mL Gadoteridol (Gd), 1 piece of PBS tablets, and 1 mL sodium azide into the 989 mL PBS (called Gd-PBS). Solve 10 mL of Gd into 990 mL paraformaldehyde (called Gd-PFA).
Put PFA and Gd-PFA into the refrigerator to cool them at 4°C.
Fix the embryos (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2895-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Step-by-step protocol to dissect the mouse embryo
(A–H) White arrow: cut direction by sessors. Red dot: cut along with the red dot to remove the uterine horn. (H) In case the embryo is big, make a small hole helps to invade 4% PFA into the embryo.
Euthanize by cervical dislocation pregnant mice (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Wipe the pregnant mouse with ethanol and open the abdomen with scissors (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
Remove the embryo and place it on a petri dish containing PBS (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D and 1E).
After washing with PBS, transfer to a fresh dish containing PBS and remove the embryo (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]F).
Wash the removed embryo in PBS, transfer it in 4% PFA, and store it in at 4 °C at least 1 day (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]G). It can be stored until 12 months. The larger samples can also be perfusion fixed with more days for fixation depending on the sample size.
In the case of large samples that do not penetrate PFA well, making a small hole is also effective (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]H).
Move the specimens to PBS or Gd-PBS and store them at 4°C.
Fix the wasp.

Naturally died wasp in the winter is used.
Put the specimens into the PFA or Gd-PFA.
Store the solution in the refrigerator at 4°C until the scan. It can be stored until 12 months.
Transfer the specimens into the PBS or Gd-PBS.
Store the fixed wasp at 4°C.
Make PS-PBS samples
Timing: 30 min
Make PS-PBS or Gd-PS-PBS solution.
Prepare 7.25 g of potato starch powder and 5 mL PBS (or 5 mL Gd-PBS if a contrast agent is required) at room temperature.
Prepare 7.25 g of potato starch powder and 5 mL PBS (or 5 mL Gd-PBS if a contrast agent is required) at room temperature. This concentration provides enough to decrease the proton signal from water around the embryo.
Put the potato starch powder into the PBS or Gd-PBS gradually.
Wait 10 s.
Mix the PS and solution with a Pasteur pipette.
Make samples.
Place the specimen into the tube. Tubes with inner diameters similar to the size of the specimen should be used.
Note: Tube diameter smaller than the size of the specimen should not be selected because the deformation of the specimen will occur.
Repeat from i to ii until penetration of potato starch covers the whole specimen.
Mix the potato starch and PBS with a Pasteur pipette.
Tilt the tube and add the PS-PBS or Gd-PS-PBS into the tube with a Pasteur pipette little by little.
Remove supernatant PBS or Gd-PBS with a Pasteur pipette.
Note: The specimen will float when PS-PBS or PS-Gd-PBS is rapidly added.
Wait for 10–30 min until the PS sinks to the bottom completely.

Confirm that the specimen is within the PS and it does not move by eyes. A part of the specimen is visible when you chose the correct size of the tube, which is fit to the size of the specimen.
Note: The supernatant should not remain a lot. Because global shimming in MRI corrected the field homogeneity including the supernatant, the contamination of signals from the supernatant may affect the adjustment of the global shimming.
Prepare for micro-MRI
Timing: 24 h
Set the tube into the MRI magnet. We show the example with an 11.7T vertical magnet.
Mark the right position, which is the center of the magnetic field, with magic pen (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
Put the tube at the right position in the radio frequency coil. Immobilize the tube tightly with the tape and sponges (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).

Place the MRI bed into the MR bore.
MRI scanning
Adjust the tuning and matching under the wobble mode.
Start the tripilot sequence. It adjusts the field homogeneity, shimming, and reference pulse gain automatically.
Scan the T1-weighted or T2-weighted images of mouse embryo or wasp. Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3] and 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4] show the example of micro-MRI with Gd-treated specimens.
For the mouse embryo, a T1-weighted image was scanned with a 3D-fast low angle shot (FLASH) following parameters:

TE/TR = 6/60 ms, flip angle = 90 degree, field-of-view (FOV) = 15 × 15 × 10 mm3, matrix = 512 × 512 × 200, resolution = 29 × 29 × 20 μm3/voxel, Average = 20, total scan time = 11 h 22 min.
For the mouse embryo, T2-weighted image was scanned with the rapid acquisition with relaxation enhancement (RARE) following parameters:
TE/TR = 40/5,000 ms, FOV = 20 × 20 mm3, matrix = 512 × 512, resolution = 39 × 39 μm2/voxel, slice thickness = 100 μm, 100 slices, RARE factor = 4, Average = 20, total scan time = 2 h 50 min.
For wasp, T1-weighted image was scanned with FLASH following parameters:
TE/TR = 4.1/60 ms, FOV = 27 × 20 × 15 mm3, matrix = 540 × 400 × 150, resolution = 50 × 50 × 100 μm3/voxel, flip angle = 90 degree, Average = 20, total scan time = 20 h.
After MRI scanning
Timing: 30 min
Remove the specimen from PS suspension (Methods video S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3]).
Mix the deposited potato starch with a Pasteur pipette.
Check that the specimen floats.
Remove the PS suspension by a Pasteur pipette.
Gently pick up the sample with tweezers and pull it out of the solution.
Wash the specimen with PBS.
Transfer the specimen into PBS or Gd-PBS.
Note: The potato starch suspension is conservative for at least six months and it can be re-used.
